They saw him as a hostile entity. From the time that he defied Gandhi, stood for election as Congress President and won, it was clear that he was hostile to Gandhi and all who followed him, some following him blindly, some following him in spite of severe reservations about his decisions. Second, his basic policies were rooted in authoritarian attitudes. He wanted anything but democracy, and apparently wanted some form of unquestioned obedience to an autocrat (guess who!) for a few years after gaining independence. Third, that itself, the gaining of independence, was a matter on which his strategy and that of the Congress diverged widely. He was looking for a military solution; the Congress, the opposite.
